title: Sir Clive Woodward and Jonny Wilkinson hail England 'superheroes' after New Zealand win
text:
Get the biggest daily news stories by email Subscribe Thank you for subscribing We have more newsletters Show me See our privacy notice Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email

England's 2003 World Cup winners Sir Clive Woodward and Jonny Wilkinson hailed Eddie Jones' Red Rose "superheroes" following their stunning semi-final triumph over New Zealand.

Jones' side produced one of their greatest-ever displays to storm into the World Cup final with a 19-7 victory over the All Blacks that reduced the reigning champions to a rabble.

From the moment Manu Tuilagi crossed after 97 seconds an extraordinary match beckoned and the final scoreline did little justice to the domination of Jones' men, who were superior in every single facet of the game.

New Zealand had won their previous 18 World Cup matches dating back to 2007 but at International Stadium Yokohama they were flattened by a juggernaut led by the unstoppable Maro Itoje.

(Image: AFP via Getty Images)

And Jonny Wilkinson, England's hero when winning in 2003, said his country had a team of "superheroes".

"You look at the back-row guys, Tom Curry and Sam Underhill, their impact, it's immense," he said on ITV.

"It's easy to look at New Zealand and call them superheroes, but you have to do the same thing for our boys and give them credit.

"That's a result of immense talent and training, Eddie Jones has created an incredible environment in which these guys can do what they have done. They are on a par with these New Zealand superheroes."

(Image: PA)

World Cup-winning coach from 2003 Woodward added: "That was totally complete. They strangled the All Blacks to death, not just the first two minutes, but the whole game.

"The physicality, 1-15, was fantastic. It was huge and totally deserved. They absolutely smashed them."

England will face either South Africa or Wales in next Saturday's final and having crushed the odds-on favourites to win the Webb Ellis Trophy, they will be expected to repeat their solitary triumph of 2003.
description: England produced one of their greatest-ever displays to storm into the 2019 Rugby World Cup final
